title: 114_hr2003
content: The Act is titled the "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" and pertains to the distribution of death information by the Social Security Administration. The "Stopping Improper Payments to Deceased People Act" amends Section 205(r) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to transmit information on deceased individuals to ensure completeness, timeliness, and accuracy, with safeguards to protect the information. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal or state agencies for benefit programs, with safeguards in place to protect the data. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal or state agencies for benefit programs, ensuring proper payment of benefits through cooperative arrangements with agencies or their Inspector Generals. Reimbursement for costs incurred in maintaining this information must be provided, and the arrangement should not conflict with the Commissioner's duties. The Commissioner of Social Security can share information on deceased individuals with federal agencies for specific purposes, such as operating the Do Not Pay working system. This cooperation must not conflict with the Commissioner's duties and should ensure proper benefit payments. The Do Not Pay working system can be operated by federal agencies to compare death information with personally identifiable information for proper payment certification, disbursement, and prevention of improper payments. Additionally, it can be used for tax administration or debt collection purposes. The Commissioner of Social Security can share deceased individuals' information with States for various purposes, including payment certification, tax administration, and crime prevention by federal policing agencies. The Commissioner of Social Security can share deceased individuals' information with States for specific purposes, such as state-funded programs or retirement systems, as long as certain requirements are met. This information can also be used for various other purposes, subject to certain conditions. The Commissioner of Social Security can share deceased individuals' information for statistical and research purposes with Federal and State agencies, ensuring safeguards are in place to protect the data. The Commissioner of Social Security can share deceased individuals' information with Federal and State agencies for statistical purposes, with specific requirements to be met. Amendments made to certain sections of the Social Security Act will be repealed after 5 years, restoring the original provisions. The provisions of section 205(r) of the Social Security Act are repealed and restored, while amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding the sharing of deceased individuals' information by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for use by Federal agencies, including State agencies, to assess accuracy and completeness. The Office of Management and Budget will review potential alternative sources of death data maintained by non-Federal sources, including State agencies, for use by Federal agencies. The review will analyze the accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability of the data compared to the death data distributed by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Office of Management and Budget will review alternative sources of death data for Federal agencies, comparing accuracy, completeness, interoperability, accessibility, cost, security, and reliability to data from the Commissioner of Social Security. A report with recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The report will include a recommendation from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget on extending agency access to death data from the Commissioner of Social Security beyond the specified repeal date. SEC. 3 of the Improper Payments Elimination and Recovery Improvement Act of 2012 is amended to include SEC. 7, which focuses on improving the use of death data by government agencies. The Office of Management and Budget will issue guidance to agencies on improving data matching with death databases for beneficiaries and annuity recipients within 6 months of the enactment of this section. The Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist states, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing access to death databases within 6 months of enactment. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will develop a plan to assist States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations in providing electronic records of individuals' deaths to the Federal Government, including recommendations for statutory changes or financial assistance. This plan may also include recommendations for funding to implement it. Additionally, a report to Congress on improving data matching will be submitted. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a plan to Congress within 270 days to enhance data matching for payments to deceased individuals by States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations receiving federal benefits. The plan may recommend funding for implementation. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a plan to Congress to improve data matching for payments to deceased individuals by States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations receiving federal benefits. Additionally, annual reports on the implementation of this plan will be submitted for the next 4 years. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the plan for improving data matching for payments to deceased individuals by States, local agencies, Indian tribes, and tribal organizations. The report will include recommendations required under subsection (a)(2) and definitions of 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' as per the Indian Self-Determination and Education Assistance Act. SEC. 4. PLAN FOR ENSURING THE ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF DEATH DATA MAINTAINED BY THE SOCIAL SECURITY ADMINISTRATION. The Commissioner of Social Security, in consultation with the Secretary of Commerce, must submit a plan to Congress within 90 days of the enactment of the Act to ensure the accuracy and completeness of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration. The plan should include procedures for identifying extremely elderly individuals still alive according to records and improving policies for identification. The plan to ensure accuracy of death data maintained by the Social Security Administration includes procedures for identifying extremely elderly individuals still alive, improving policies for correcting erroneous records, and identifying errors in the Numerical Identification System and death data. The plan requires the Social Security Administration to implement procedures for identifying living elderly individuals, improving policies to correct errors in records, and conducting statistical analysis to estimate the number of erroneous records. Recommendations for legislation are also included. The Commissioner of Social Security must implement the plan within 2 years of the Act's enactment.
